article.title: RAGE::SDL : The C++ wrapper for SDL

section.title: Features
section.para: This library is mostly a C++ portable layer over the Smart DirectMedia Library. The aim is to have a C++ interface to SDL. Users should be able to use it simply and have at least a "default consistent behaviour".
AS soon as the wrapping of SDL is complete, we will start looking at wrapping all the SDL "Standard Libs" in the same way.

section.title: Graphic Interface
section.para: The graphic interface is a pure virtual class called "Engine". you need to derivate it with you own if you want to be able to display something in your SDL window. You can use either OpenGL functions or RAGE::SDL 2D functions, providing you created the Window with the correct settings.
If you are using 2D functions you might want to the Video Interface inside the Engine.

section.title: Input Interface
section.para: The input interface is made by EventManager, Joystick, Keyboard, Mouse. You will probably need to extend them to implement the behaviour you want.

section.title: How to build, test and install
Code::Blocks build
section.para: I am personnaly using CodeBlocks on windows with mingw to build RAGE::SDL. However it misses a dependency checking for the libraries needed. At the moment it is not a big problem as only SDL is needed. But while we will add more dependencies CMake will be used to have a consistent way of building RAGE::SDL.

para.emphasis: Makefiles can be generated from Cmake for most of the unix platforms. Not tested yet.

section.title: CMake build
section.para: If you dont use either Codeblocks, or make files, and want to be able to build RAGE::SDL using your own favorite environment, try the CMake build. It generates files for most of the compilers / build system.
The good thing with CMake is that it will check the dependencies available on your system and help you to configure your system for development.

section.title: Testing RAGE::SDL
section.para: There are a few test that are usefull to test the C++ wrapper. most of them are still the old SDL tests, not yet using the wrapper... lots of work to do.
